 {{Elections in Washington State}}
 
 The '''2020 Washington gubernatorial election''' will be held on November 3, 2020, to elect the [[governor of Washington]], concurrently with the [[2020 United States presidential election|2020 U.S. presidential election]], as well as [[2020 United States Senate elections|elections]] to the [[United States Senate]], [[2020 United States House of Representatives elections|elections]] to the [[United States House of Representatives]] and various [[2020 United States elections|state and local elections]]. The [[Nonpartisan blanket primary|top-two primary]] was held on August 4.
  
 Washington does not have gubernatorial term limits and incumbent [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] Governor [[Jay Inslee]] is running for a third term.<ref>{{cite news |last=Merica |first=Dan |title=Washington Gov. Jay Inslee announces 2020 presidential bid |url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/03/01/politics/inslee-2020-presidential-campaign/index.html |date=March 1, 2019 |accessdate=March 1, 2019}}</ref> Inslee initially [[Jay Inslee 2020 presidential campaign|launched a campaign]] for [[President of the United States]] in [[2020 United States presidential election|the 2020 election]]. When he dropped out of that race in August 2019 due to low polling numbers,<ref>{{Cite web|date=2019-10-21|title=Was Jay Inslee’s presidential campaign a failure?|url=https://theaggie.org/2019/10/21/was-jay-inslees-presidential-campaign-a-failure/|access-date=2020-10-20|website=The Aggie|language=en-US}}</ref> he announced he would seek a third term as governor.<ref>{{cite news |last1=CNN |first1=Dan Merica and Paul LeBlanc |title=Washington Gov. Jay Inslee drops out of presidential race |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2019/08/21/politics/jay-inslee-drops-out-of-race/index.html |accessdate=August 22, 2019 |work=CNN |date=August 22, 2019}}</ref> Several other Democratic political figures considered entering the race if Inslee did not run, including [[Attorney General of Washington|Washington Attorney General]] [[Bob Ferguson (politician)|Bob Ferguson]], but ultimately, no major Democrats entered the race.<ref>{{cite news |last=Gutman |first=David |date=August 22, 2019 |title=With Inslee running again for governor, leading Washington state Democrats put their ambitions on hold |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/politics/with-inslee-running-again-for-governor-leading-washington-state-democrats-put-their-ambitions-on-hold/ |work=The Seattle Times |accessdate=August 22, 2019}}</ref> Inslee is the first governor of Washington to seek a third term since [[Daniel J. Evans]] in [[1972 Washington gubernatorial election|1972]].
 
 ==Background==
 Washington has not had a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] governor since [[John Spellman]] left office in 1985, the longest streak of Democratic leadership of any state in the country and the third longest streak of one-party leadership after [[South Dakota]] (which has not had a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] governor since [[Harvey L. Wollman]] left office in 1979) and [[Utah]] (which has not had a Democratic governor since [[Scott M. Matheson]] left office nine days prior to Spellman in 1985).<ref name="UT">{{cite news |last1=Wood |first1=Benjamin |title=achary Moses, a Democratic candidate for governor, wants to break up Republican control of Utah and build a space port |url=https://www.sltrib.com/news/politics/2019/07/19/zachary-moses-democratic/ |accessdate=August 29, 2019 |work=Salt Lake Tribune |date=July 19, 2019}}</ref><ref name="SD">{{cite news |last1=Scott |first1=Dylan |title=Kristi Noem elected first woman governor of South Dakota |url=https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2018/11/7/18055928/midterm-election-results-south-dakota-governor-kristi-noem-winner |accessdate=August 26, 2019 |work=Vox |date=November 7, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Camden |first1=Jim |title=John Spellman, Washington's last Republican governor, dies |url=https://www.spokesman.com/stories/2018/jan/16/former-gov-spellman-dies/ |accessdate=August 23, 2019 |publisher=The Spokesman-Review |date=January 16, 2018}}</ref> Incumbent Governor [[Jay Inslee]], who previously served in the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. House]], was first elected to the governorship in [[2012 Washington gubernatorial election|the 2012 election]] and won reelection [[2016 Washington gubernatorial election|in 2016]].
 
 When Inslee announced [[Jay Inslee 2020 presidential campaign|his candidacy]] for president, several political figures expressed interest in running for Governor if Inslee won [[2020 Democratic Party presidential primaries|the Democratic primaries]]. These included [[List of Attorneys General of Washington|Attorney General]] [[Bob Ferguson (politician)|Bob Ferguson]], [[Washington State Department of Natural Resources#Commissioner of Public Lands|Commissioner of Public Lands]] [[Hilary Franz]] and [[King County, Washington|King County]] executive [[Dow Constantine]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |url=https://www.king5.com/article/news/politics/king-county-executive-dow-constantine-not-ruling-out-run-for-governor/281-b1ecff63-ef9e-49ee-8fd6-992706c85b26 |title=King County Executive Dow Constantine not ruling out run for governor |publisher=KING 5 News |access-date=February 25, 2019}}</ref> They stated they would only run if Inslee was not, avoiding a [[primary challenge]].<ref name="inslee bid">{{cite news |last1=Axelrod |first1=Tal |title=Inslee to announce bid for third term as Washington governor: report |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/458382-inslee-to-announce-bid-for-third-term-as-washington-governor-report |website=The Hill |date=August 22, 2019 |accessdate=August 22, 2019}}</ref><ref name="ferg run">{{cite news |last1=Smay |first1=Ian |title=Bob Ferguson announces decision to run for another term as Washington Attorney General |url=https://www.king5.com/article/news/politics/bob-ferguson-announces-decision-to-run-for-another-term-as-washington-attorney-general/281-9ea0147a-9c8c-4b05-aae6-5d4e79eb8bea |publisher=KING 5 News |date=August 22, 2019 |accessdate=August 22, 2019}}</ref> Inslee was the sole major Democratic candidate to enter the race.
 
 Several [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] politicians announced their own campaigns to challenge Inslee, including businessman Anton Sakharov, [[Republic, Washington|Republic]] police chief Loren Culp, and [[Washington State Senate|state senator]] [[Phil Fortunato]].<ref name="chief run">{{cite web |last1=Robinson |first1=Erin |title=Republic police chief announces run for governor |url=https://www.kxly.com/news/republic-police-chief-announces-run-for-governor/1100205481 |publisher=KXLY |accessdate=August 2, 2019 |date=July 26, 2019}}</ref><ref name="fort gear">{{Cite web |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/politics/gop-state-senator-phil-fortunato-gears-up-for-governor-run/ |title=GOP State Senator Phil Fortunato gears up for governor run |date=August 5, 2019 |work=The Seattle Times |language=en-US|access-date=August 6, 2019}}</ref>
 
 ==Democratic candidates==

 '''Yvette Herrell'''<ref name="PVS">{{Cite web |title=Yvette Herrell's Biography |url=https://justfacts.votesmart.org/candidate/biography/121681/yvette-herrell |access-date=April 3, 2020 |publisher=[[Project Vote Smart]]}}</ref> is an [[United States|American]] politician, businesswoman, and real estate agent who is the Representative-elect for [[New Mexico's 2nd congressional district]]. She previously served as a member of the [[New Mexico House of Representatives]] for District 51 from January 18, 2011 until January 15, 2019.<ref name="NML">{{Cite web |title=Representative Yvette Herrell (R) |url=http://www.nmlegis.gov/lcs/legislator_details.aspx?SPONCODE=HHERY |access-date=February 12, 2014 |publisher=[[New Mexico Legislature]] |location=[[Santa Fe, New Mexico]]}}</ref>
 
 Herrell was the Republican nominee for [[New Mexico's 2nd congressional district]] in the 2018 elections. She was defeated by [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] [[Xochitl Torres Small]]. Herrell again became the Republican nominee for the [[New Mexico's 2nd congressional district|2nd district]] in 2020, defeating [[Xochitl Torres Small|Torres Small]] in the November general election.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Edmondson|first=Catie|date=2020-11-04|title=Yvette Herrell Ousts Xochitl Torres Small From New Mexico House Seat|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/04/us/politics/new-mexico-yvette-herrell.html|access-date=2020-11-04|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> She is the third Native American woman elected to Congress, the second Native woman from New Mexico and the first Republican Native Woman.
 
 == Early life and education ==
 Born in [[Ruidoso, New Mexico]], Herrell is a member of the [[Cherokee Nation]].<ref name="native">{{Cite web |last=Olmstead |first=Mallory |date=November 6, 2018 |title=Two Native American Women Become First Elected to Congress |url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2018/11/sharice-davids-deb-haaland-first-native-american-women-elected-congress.html |website=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]}}</ref><ref>[http://tn--npta2.www3.capwiz.com/bio/id/65799]</ref> After attending Cloudcroft High School, Herrell earned a legal secretary diploma from the [[ITT Technical Institute]] School of Business in [[Boise, Idaho]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Candidate |first=The |title=2nd Congressional District candidate Yvette Herrell |url=https://www.abqjournal.com/1167038/2nd-congressional-district-candidate-yvette-herrell.html |access-date=2020-06-03 |website=www.abqjournal.com |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Candidate |first=The |title=Q&A: Congressional District 2 Yvette Herrell |url=https://www.abqjournal.com/1451187/qa-congressional-district-2-yvette-herrell.html |access-date=2020-06-03 |website=www.abqjournal.com |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Barbati |first=Duane |title=Yvette Herrell running for Congressional seat vacated by Pearce |url=https://www.alamogordonews.com/story/news/local/community/2017/07/12/yvette-herrell-running-congressional-seat-vacated-pearce/470703001/ |access-date=2020-06-05 |website=Alamogordo Daily News |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Devine |first=Jacqueline |title=Incumbent Herrell looking to retain state District 51 seat |url=https://www.alamogordonews.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/10/20/incumbent-herrell-looking-retain-state-district-51-seat/92480262/ |access-date=2020-06-05 |website=Alamogordo Daily News |language=en}}</ref>

|accessdate=2019-09-03}}</ref>
 
 In February 2017, Van Duyne announced she would not seek a third term as mayor.<ref name="third term">{{cite web|author=|url=https://www.dallasnews.com/news/irving/2017/02/16/irving-mayor-beth-van-duyne-will-seek-third-term |title=Irving Mayor Beth Van Duyne will not seek third term | Irving |work=Dallas News |date= |accessdate=2019-08-06}}</ref> In May 2017, [[President of the United States|President]] [[Donald Trump]] appointed Van Duyne as a regional administrator for the [[United States Department of Housing and Urban Development]] (HUD), overseeing Texas, Oklahoma, New Mexico, Louisiana, and Arkansas.<ref>{{cite web|author=Brandon Formby |url=https://www.texastribune.org/2017/05/08/trump-taps-irving-mayor-beth-van-duyne-regional-hud-administrator/ |title=Trump names Irving Mayor Beth Van Duyne regional HUD administrator |work=The Texas Tribune |date=2017-05-08 |accessdate=2019-08-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Simek |first=Peter |url=https://www.dmagazine.com/frontburner/2017/08/former-irving-mayor-faces-tough-road-with-houston-catastrophe/ |title=Former Irving Mayor Faces Tough Road Leading HUD Through Houston Catastrophe |work=D Magazine |date=2017-08-29 |accessdate=2019-08-06}}</ref>
 ===2020 24th Congressional District campaign===
 {{Main|2020 United States House of Representatives elections in Texas#District 24}}
 Following [[Kenny Marchant]]'s August 2019 announcement that he would not run for reelection to the [[United States House of Representatives]], Van Duyne announced her resignation from HUD so that she could run in the [[2020 United States House of Representatives elections#District 24|2020 elections]] to succeed Marchant in representing {{ushr|TX|24}}, a suburban stretch between Dallas and Fort Worth, including parts of [[Denton County, Texas|Denton]], [[Dallas County, Texas|Dallas]], and [[Tarrant County, Texas|Tarrant]] counties.<ref>{{cite web|last=Heinz |first=Frank |url=https://www.nbcdfw.com/news/politics/Beth-Van-Duyne-Leaving-HUD-Running-for-Kenny-Marchants-District-24-Seat-521555481.html |title=Beth Van Duyne Leaving HUD, Running for Kenny Marchant's District 24 Seat |website=[[NBCDFW]] |date=2019-08-05 |accessdate=2019-08-06}}</ref><ref name="BI08282020"/> On March 3, 2020, Van Duyne defeated four other Republicans in the Republican Party primary with about 65% of the vote.<ref>Zeeble, Bill & Syeda Hasan. [https://www.keranews.org/politics/2020-03-04/in-texas-24th-house-district-van-duyne-wins-gop-race-runoff-for-democrats In Texas 24th House District, Van Duyne Wins GOP Race, Runoff For Democrats], ''[[KERA-TV]], North Texas Public Broadcasting, Inc.'', [[Dallas, Texas]], March 4, 2020. Retrieved September 15, 2020.</ref> President [[Donald Trump]] endorsed Van Duyne in the primary.<ref>Bowman, Bridget. [https://www.rollcall.com/2020/02/26/where-do-democrats-want-to-expand-their-house-majority-look-no-further-than-texas-24th-district/ Where do Democrats want to expand their House majority? Look no further than Texas’ 24th District], ''[[Roll Call]]'', February 26, 2020. Retrieved September 15, 2020.</ref> 
 
 Van Duyne will face the Democratic candidate, Candace Valenzuela, a former [[Carrollton-Farmers Branch Independent School District|Carrollton-Farmers Branch]] school board member, in the general election.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/latino/candace-valenzuela-wins-texas-runoff-stands-be-first-afro-latina-n1233829 |title=Candace Valenzuela wins Texas runoff, stands to be first Afro-Latina in Congress |publisher=Nbcnews.com |date= |accessdate=July 15, 2020}}</ref>  Van Duyne has raised, according to the [[Center for Responsive Politics]], $1.4 million, about $300,000 more than her opponent.<ref name="BI08282020">Panetta, Grace. [https://www.businessinsider.com/texas-house-24th-district-election-beth-van-duyne-candace-valenzuela-2020 Everything you need to know about Texas' 24th Congressional District House race between Beth Van Duyne and Candace Valenzuela], ''Business Insider'', August 28, 2020. Retrieved September 16, 2020.</ref> Van Duyne opposes the Affordable Care Act, saying it "has done profound damage to the healthcare of Americans."<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|date=2020-10-20|title=Beth Van Duyne, Candace Valenzuela Battle For North Texas' Open 24th Congressional Seat Considered Toss-Up|url=https://dfw.cbslocal.com/2020/10/20/beth-van-duyne-candace-valenzuela-24th-congressional-seat-texas-toss-up/|access-date=2020-10-30|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Voter guide: Questionnaire for Beth Van Duyne, candidate for United States Representative|url=https://voterguide.dallasnews.com/2020-primary/candidates/1143/|access-date=2020-10-30|website=voterguide.dallasnews.com|language=en}}</ref> During the campaign, she ran advertisements concerning health care, where she says she will protect laws that require [[pre-existing condition]]s to be covered by insurance.<ref>Zanona, Melanie. [https://www.politico.com/newsletters/huddle/2020/08/25/coronavirus-poses-new-threat-to-endangered-texas-republicans-490179 Coronavirus poses new threat to endangered Texas Republicans], ''[[Politico]]'', August 25, 2020. Retrieved September 16, 2020.</ref>
 
 == Controversies ==
 
 During the election campaign, Van Duyne held events where she did not wear a face mask and did not socially distance, in contradiction to public health guidance.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|date=2020-10-23|title=Mask wearing has been politicized, and now is a defining issue in a hot North Texas congressional race|url=https://www.dallasnews.com/news/politics/2020/10/23/mask-wearing-has-been-politicized-and-now-is-a-defining-issue-in-a-hot-north-texas-congressional-race/|access-date=2020-10-30|website=Dallas News|language=en}}</ref>
 
 Van Duyne criticized her opponent, Valenzuela, as a "coward" for not campaigning in person amid the coronavirus pandemic.<ref name=":1" /> At the time, Valenzuela lived with her elderly mother-in-law who was at high risk of harm if she was exposed to COVID-19.<ref name=":1" /> Van Duyne praised the Trump administration's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic.<ref name=":0" />
 
-On criminal justice reform, Van Duyne is opposed to ending cash bail.<ref name=":0" />
-
 == Personal life ==
 Van Duyne met her former husband, Chris "Casey" Wallach, while they were attending [[Cornell University]].<ref name="energy and dedication" /> They have two children,<ref name="dispute">{{cite web|url=https://www.dallasnews.com/news/news/2015/03/24/dispute-over-islam-lands-irving-mayor-beth-van-duyne-on-national-stage|title=Dispute over Islam lands Irving Mayor Beth Van Duyne on national stage | News|author=|date=2015-03-24|work=The Dallas Morning News|accessdate=2019-08-06}}</ref> and divorced in 2012 after being married for 17 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dallasnews.com/news/2012/09/28/in-bid-for-privacy-irving-mayor-files-for-divorce-using-her-initials/|title=In bid for privacy, Irving mayor files for divorce using her initials|first=Brandon|last=Formby|work=The Dallas Morning News|date=September 28, 2012|accessdate=September 14, 2020}}</ref>

 In February 2017, Van Duyne announced she would not seek a third term as mayor.<ref name="third term">{{cite web|author=|url=https://www.dallasnews.com/news/irving/2017/02/16/irving-mayor-beth-van-duyne-will-seek-third-term |title=Irving Mayor Beth Van Duyne will not seek third term | Irving |work=Dallas News |date= |accessdate=2019-08-06}}</ref> In May 2017, [[President of the United States|President]] [[Donald Trump]] appointed Van Duyne as a regional administrator for the [[United States Department of Housing and Urban Development]] (HUD), overseeing Texas, Oklahoma, New Mexico, Louisiana, and Arkansas.<ref>{{cite web|author=Brandon Formby |url=https://www.texastribune.org/2017/05/08/trump-taps-irving-mayor-beth-van-duyne-regional-hud-administrator/ |title=Trump names Irving Mayor Beth Van Duyne regional HUD administrator |work=The Texas Tribune |date=2017-05-08 |accessdate=2019-08-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Simek |first=Peter |url=https://www.dmagazine.com/frontburner/2017/08/former-irving-mayor-faces-tough-road-with-houston-catastrophe/ |title=Former Irving Mayor Faces Tough Road Leading HUD Through Houston Catastrophe |work=D Magazine |date=2017-08-29 |accessdate=2019-08-06}}</ref>

[[Yale University]] ([[Master of Theological Studies|MAR]], [[Juris Doctor|JD]]) |website = {{url|https://coons.senate.gov|Senate website}} }} '''Christopher Andrew Coons''' (born September 9, 1963) is an American politician serving as the [[Seniority in the United States Senate|junior]] [[United States Senate|United States Senator]] from [[Delaware]] since 2010. A member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]], Coons served as the [[county executive]] of [[New Castle County, Delaware|New Castle County]] from 2005 to 2010. He was the 1983 [[Truman Scholar]] from Delaware, and the first recipient of the award to serve in the United States Senate. -Raised in [[Hockessin, Delaware]], Coons graduated from [[Amherst College]] in [[Massachusetts]], where he joined Delta Kappa Epsilon Fraternity. He received graduate degrees from [[Yale Divinity School]] and [[Yale Law School]]. He went to work as a volunteer [[relief worker]] in Kenya, where he had taken classes in the [[University of Nairobi]], later returning to the U.S. to work for the [[Coalition for the Homeless]] in New York. He spent some time as a legal clerk in New York before returning to Delaware in 1996, where he spent eight years as in-house counsel for a materials manufacturing company. In the interim he worked for several nonprofit organizations. +Raised in [[Hockessin, Delaware]], Coons graduated from [[Amherst College]] in [[Massachusetts]], where he joined [[Delta Kappa Epsilon]] Fraternity. He received graduate degrees from [[Yale Divinity School]] and [[Yale Law School]]. He went to work as a volunteer [[relief worker]] in Kenya, where he had taken classes in the [[University of Nairobi]], later returning to the U.S. to work for the [[Coalition for the Homeless]] in New York. He spent some time as a legal clerk in New York before returning to Delaware in 1996, where he spent eight years as in-house counsel for a materials manufacturing company. In the interim he worked for several nonprofit organizations. Coons served as president of the [[New Castle County Council]] from 2001 to 2005 and county executive of [[New Castle County, Delaware|New Castle County]] from 2005 to 2010. He balanced the county budget with a surplus in fiscal year 2010 by cutting spending and raising taxes, and the county maintained a [[Fitch Group|AAA bond rating]]. Coons contested the [[2010 United States Senate special election in Delaware|2010 Senate special election for Delaware]]. He defeated the Republican nominee, [[Christine O'Donnell]], to succeed [[Ted Kaufman]], who had been appointed to the seat when [[Joe Biden]] resigned to become [[Vice President of the United States]]. He was elected to a full term [[United States Senate election in Delaware, 2014|in 2014]]. Coons is the vice chair of the [[United States Senate Committee on Ethics|Senate Ethics Committee]]. His other committee assignments include [[United States Senate Committee on Appropriations|Appropriations]], [[United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations|Foreign Relations]], [[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary|Judiciary]], and [[United States Senate Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship|Small Business and Entrepreneurship]]. He previously served as ranking member of the [[United States Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee on African Affairs|Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee on African Affairs]] and the [[United States Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Bankruptcy and the Courts|Judiciary Subcommittee on Bankruptcy and the Courts]].{{cite web|url=https://www.coons.senate.gov/about |title=Chris Coons Biography |publisher=www.coons.senate.gov |accessdate=December 19, 2017}} Coons was the co-chair for the 2019 [[National Prayer Breakfast]]. He previously co-chaired the 2017 National Prayer Breakfast, and co-chairs the weekly Senate Prayer Breakfast.{{cite web|url= http://time.com/5137579/national-prayer-breakfast-lankford-coons/|title=National Prayer Breakfast Co-Chairs Named |publisher=www.time.com |accessdate=February 14, 2018}} ''[[The New York Times]]'' called Coons an "effective" emissary of [[Joe Biden]] to former and current Republican lawmakers in Biden's [[Joe Biden 2020 presidential campaign|2020]] campaign for president.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/06/us/politics/trump-biden-republicans-voters.html|title=Bush, Romney and Powell wouldn't back Trump re-election|work=The New York Times}} ==Early life and education== Coons was born in [[Greenwich, Connecticut]], the son of Sarah Louise "Sally" (née Ives) and Kenelm Winslow "Ken" Coons. His ancestry includes English and Irish.{{cite web|url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~battle/senators/coons.htm |title=Chris Coons ancestry |publisher=Freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com |accessdate=October 8, 2012}} Coons grew up in [[Hockessin, Delaware]], where he attended the public Yorklyn Elementary School and later H.B. DuPont Middle School. His parents struggled financially and divorced in the mid 1970s. He and his two brothers lived with their mother for a few years until 1977, when his mother married [[Robert W. Gore]], the President of [[W. L. Gore and Associates]].{{cite news |last1=Hale |first1=Charlotte |title=Strong on Service |work=The News Journal (Wilmington, Delaware) |date=October 15, 2004 |page=B1 & B5}} He graduated from the private [[Tower Hill School]] and then [[Amherst College]] in 1985 with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in [[chemistry]] and [[political science]]. While in college, he was a member of [[Delta Kappa Epsilon]] fraternity (Sigma chapter) and a U.S. Senate intern. In 1983, Coons was awarded the [[Truman Scholarship]]. During his junior year of college, he studied abroad at the [[University of Nairobi]] in [[Kenya]] through [[St. Lawrence University]]'s Kenya Semester Program.{{cite web |url=https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2013/08/02/look-st-lawrence-universitys-study-abroad-program-kenya |title=St. Lawrence University's Kenya Semester Program |publisher=www.insidehighered.com |date= |accessdate=December 27, 2017}} In 1992, he earned a master's degree in ethics from [[Yale Divinity School]] and a [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] degree from [[Yale Law School]].{{cite web |url=http://www.chriscoons.com/about/meet_chris_coons |title=Meet Chris Coons |accessdate=December 27, 2017 |publisher=Chris Coons for U.S. Senate}} (campaign web site biography) In 2018, Delaware State University named Coons as an Honorary Doctor in Humane Letters. ==Professional career== After college, Coons worked in [[Washington, D.C.]], for the Investor Responsibility Research Center, where he wrote a book on South Africa and the U.S. [[Disinvestment from South Africa|divestment movement]]. He then worked as a volunteer for the [[South African Council of Churches]] and as a [[relief worker]] in Kenya, before returning to the U.S. to work for the National Coalition for the Homeless in New York. In 1992, he earned a J.D. degree from [[Yale Law School]], and a master's degree in [[ethics]] from [[Yale Divinity School]].{{Cite news|title = Castle vs. Coons| author=Yearick, Bob| work = Delaware Today | date = June 15, 2010| url =http://www.delawaretoday.com/Delaware-Today/July-2010/Castle-vs-Coons/index.php?cparticle=3&siarticle=2#artanc| accessdate = September 16, 2010}} Coons clerked for [[Federal Judge|Judge]] [[Jane Richards Roth]] on the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit]], and then worked for the National "I Have a Dream" Foundation in New York.{{Cite news| title = Chris Coons: Delaware's surprise favorite| publisher = CNN| date = September 15, 2010| url = http://articles.cnn.com/2010-09-15/politics/coons.profile_1_chris-coons-election-delaware?_s=PM:POLITICS| accessdate = September 16, 2010| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100917035256/http://articles.cnn.com/2010-09-15/politics/coons.profile_1_chris-coons-election-delaware?_s=PM:POLITICS| archive-date = September 17, 2010| url-status = dead}} After returning to Delaware in 1996, Coons began his eight-year career as in-house counsel for [[W.L. Gore & Associates]], Inc., [[Newark, Delaware]]-based makers of [[Gore-Tex]] fabrics and other high-tech materials. There he was responsible for the ethics training program, federal government relations, e-commerce legal work, and for general commercial contracting.

[[Samford University]] ([[Juris Doctor|JD]]) |website = {{url|jones.senate.gov|Senate website}} |signature = Djsig.svg }} '''Gordon Douglas Jones''' (born May 4, 1954) is an American attorney, former prosecutor and politician serving as the [[Seniority in the United States Senate|junior]] [[United States Senate|United States Senator]] from [[Alabama]] since 2018. A member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]], he was the [[United States Attorney]] for the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama|Northern District of Alabama]] from 1997 to 2001. Jones was born in [[Fairfield, Alabama]], and is a graduate of the [[University of Alabama]] and [[Cumberland School of Law]] at [[Samford University]]. After law school, he worked as a congressional staffer and as a federal prosecutor before moving to private practice. In 1997, President [[Bill Clinton]] appointed Jones as U.S. Attorney for the Northern District of Alabama. Jones's most prominent cases were the successful prosecution of two [[Ku Klux Klan]] members for the [[16th Street Baptist Church bombing|1963 Birmingham church bombing]] that killed four African-American girls and the indictment of domestic terrorist [[Eric Rudolph]]. He returned to private practice at the conclusion of Clinton's presidency in 2001. Jones announced his candidacy for United States Senate in the [[2017 United States Senate special election in Alabama|2017 special election]] following the resignation of Republican incumbent [[Jeff Sessions]] to become [[United States Attorney General|U.S. Attorney General]]. After winning the Democratic primary in August, he faced former [[Supreme Court of Alabama|Alabama Supreme Court]] Justice [[Roy Moore]] in the general election. Jones was considered a long-shot candidate in a [[Cook Partisan Voting Index|deeply Republican state]]. A month before the election, Moore was [[Roy Moore sexual misconduct allegations|alleged]] to have sexually assaulted and otherwise acted inappropriately with several females, including some who were minors at the time.{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/dec/12/roy-moore-loses-alabama-senate-race-doug-jones-wins|title=Alabama election: Democrats triumph over Roy Moore in major blow to Trump |last1=Jacobs |first1=Ben |last2=Smith |first2=David |date=December 13, 2017 |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=August 6, 2018}} Jones won the special election by 22,000 votes, 50%–48%.{{cite news |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/wireStory/turbulent-senate-race-now-hands-alabama-voters-51733556 |title=Democrat Jones wins stunning red-state Alabama Senate upset |author1=Chandler, Kim |date=December 13, 2017 |publisher=ABC News |agency=Associated Press |author2=Peoples, Steve |accessdate=December 13, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171217005217/https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/wireStory/turbulent-senate-race-now-hands-alabama-voters-51733556 |archive-date=December 17, 2017 |url-status=dead }} Jones is currently the only statewide elected Democrat in Alabama and the first Democrat to win statewide office since [[Lucy Baxley]] was elected President of the [[Alabama Public Service Commission]] in 2008. Democrats had not represented Alabama in the U.S. Senate since 1997, when [[Howell Heflin]] left office. Jones is considered a moderate Democrat who demonstrates a willingness to work with Republicans and split with his party on certain issues.{{cite web |last1=Beaman |first1=Jeremy |title=Sen. Hartselle.|publisher=Doug Jones for Senate|date=August 16, 2017|accessdate=August 16, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171212011108/https://dougjonesforsenate.com/|archive-date=December 12, 2017|url-status=dead}}https://obits.al.com/obituaries/birmingham/obituary.aspx?n=gordon-c-jones&pid=194881872&fhid=29437 His father worked at [[U.S. Steel]] and his mother was a homemaker.{{Citation |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/05/05/us/public-lives-an-alabama-prosecutor-confronts-the-burden-of-history.html|title=PUBLIC LIVES; An Alabama Prosecutor Confronts the Burden of History|last=Sack|first=Kevin|date=May 5, 2001|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=May 18, 2017}} Jones graduated from the [[University of Alabama]] with a [[Bachelor of Science]] in political science in 1976, and earned his [[Juris Doctor]] from [[Cumberland School of Law]] at [[Samford University]] in 1979. He is a member of [[Beta Theta Pi]].{{cite news |last1=Cobb |first1=Martin |title=Brother Senator |url=https://issuu.com/betathetapiao/docs/beta_theta_pi_sping_2018/10 |work=The Beta Theta Pi |date=Spring 2018 |page=10 |accessdate=18 June 2018 }} Jones's political career began as staff counsel to the [[U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee]] for Alabama Senator [[Howell Heflin]].{{Cite news |url=http://www.al.com/news/index.ssf/2017/05/doug_jones_announces_run_for_u.html|title=Doug Jones announces run for US Senate|last=Gray|first=Jeremy|date=May 11, 2017 |newspaper=[[The Birmingham News]] |accessdate=May 18, 2017}} Jones then worked as an [[Assistant U.S. Attorney]] from 1980 to 1984 before resigning to work at a private law firm in [[Birmingham, Alabama]], from 1984 to 1997.{{cite web|url=http://www.publicjustice.org/uploads/file/pdf/Murnaghan_Lecture_flyer_Douglas_Jones_bio.pdf|title=Douglas Jones|last=Murnaghan|publisher=Public Justice|accessdate=May 18, 2017}} ==U.S. Attorney== President [[Bill Clinton]] announced on August 18, 1997, his intent to appoint Jones as U.S. Attorney for the Northern District of Alabama,{{Cite press release|url=https://clinton6.nara.gov/1997/08/1997-08-18-douglas-jones-nominated-as-us-attorney-in-alabama.html|title=President Clinton today announced his intent to nominate G. Douglas Jones to serve as United States Attorney for the Northern District of Alabama.|publisher=[[White House Office of the Press Secretary]]|date=August 18, 1997|access-date=May 18, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111025122641/http://clinton6.nara.gov/1997/08/1997-08-18-douglas-jones-nominated-as-us-attorney-in-alabama.html|archive-date=October 25, 2011|url-status=dead}} and formally nominated Jones to the post on September 2, 1997.[http://readingroom.law.gsu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1745&context=gsulr Panel Discussion: Criminal Discovery In Practice], 15 [[Georgia State University Law Review|Ga. St. U. L. Rev.]] 781, 782 n.2 (1999). On September 8, 1997, the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Alabama appointed Jones as interim U.S. Attorney. The [[United States Senate|Senate]] confirmed Jones's nomination on November 8, 1997, by [[voice vote]].{{cite news |first=John |last=Verhoevek |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/alabama-senate-race-pits-doug-jones-roy-moore/story?id=50127528 |title=Meet the Alabama Senate candidates: Controversial gun-toting judge Roy Moore and a lawyer who fought the KKK |publisher=ABC News |date=September 27, 2017}} In January 1998, [[Eric Rudolph]] bombed the New Woman All Women Health Care Center in Birmingham. Jones was responsible for coordinating the state and federal task force in the aftermath, and advocated that Rudolph be tried first in Birmingham before being extradited and tried in Georgia for his crimes in that state, such as the [[Centennial Olympic Park bombing]].{{Cite news |url=https://abcnews.go.com/US/story?id=90596&page=1|title=Bombing Suspect Eric Rudolph Indicted|date=November 15, 2000|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=May 18, 2017}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/06/03/us/bombing-suspect-is-moved-to-alabama-for-trial-there-first.html|title=Bombing Suspect Is Moved to Alabama, for Trial There First|last=Gettlman|first=Jeffrey|date=June 3, 2003|newspaper=The New York Times}} ===16th Street Baptist Church bombing case=== [[File:Doug Jones Cherry Trial (cropped).jpg|thumb|150px|Jones during the trial of Bobby Frank Cherry]] Jones prosecuted [[Thomas Edwin Blanton Jr.]] and [[Bobby Frank Cherry]], two members of the [[Ku Klux Klan]], for their roles in the 1963 [[16th Street Baptist Church bombing]]. The case was reopened the year before Jones was appointed, but did not gain traction until his appointment. A [[federal grand jury]] was called in 1998, which caught the attention of Cherry's ex-wife, Willadean Cherry, and led her to call the FBI to give her testimony. Willadean then introduced Jones to family and friends, who reported their own experiences from the time of the bombing. A key piece of evidence was a tape from the time of the bombing in which Blanton said he had plotted with others to make the bomb. Jones was deputized to argue in state court and indicted Blanton and Cherry in 2000.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/04/25/us/church-bombing-trial-begins-birmingham-city-s-past-very-much-present.html|title=As Church Bombing Trial Begins in Birmingham, the City's Past Is Very Much Present|last=Sack|first=Kevin|date=April 25, 2001 |newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=May 18, 2017}}{{Cite news |url=https://articles.latimes.com/2013/sep/14/nation/la-na-nn-birmingham-bombing-prosecutor-20130913|title=Prosecutor reflects on 50th anniversary of 1963 Birmingham bombing|last=Hennessy-Fiske|first=Molly|date=September 14, 2013 |newspaper=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=May 18, 2017}} Blanton was found guilty in 2001 and Cherry in 2002. Both were sentenced to life in prison. Blanton was up for parole in 2016; Jones spoke against his release, and parole was denied. Cherry died in prison in 2004.{{Cite news |url=http://www.al.com/news/birmingham/index.ssf/2016/08/alabama_board_considering_paro.html|title=16th Street Baptist Church bomber Thomas Blanton denied parole|last=Faulk|first=Kent|date=August 3, 2016|newspaper=[[The Birmingham News]] |accessdate=May 18, 2017}}{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A61428-2004Nov18.html|title=Birmingham Bomber Bobby Frank Cherry Dies in Prison at 74|last=Lamb|first=Yvonne|date=November 19, 2004|newspaper=The Washington Post|accessdate=May 18, 2017}} {{external media| float = left| video1 = [https://www.c-span.org/video/?457874-1/after-words-senator-doug-jones ''After Words'' interview with Jones on ''Bending Toward Justice'', March 9, 2019], [[C-SPAN]]}}

 ===Abortion===
 In 2017, Bullock vetoed measures to outlaw [[abortion]]s after 20 weeks, citing constitutional rulings on the women's ability to protect their lives and health and arguing that elected officials should not put personal beliefs above medical professionals' judgment.<ref>{{cite web |title=Abortion, guns, state plane among bills vetoed by governor |url=https://apnews.com/article/3cd844d6f8f643c897d132c930f19379 |website=[[Associated Press]] |date=5 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Governor Bullock Stands With Montana Families By Vetoing Extreme Bills Endangering Women|url=https://www.aclumontana.org/en/press-releases/governor-bullock-stands-montana-families-vetoing-extreme-bills-endangering-women|website=American Civil Liberties 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180702093732/https://www.aclumontana.org/en/press-releases/governor-bullock-stands-montana-families-vetoing-extreme-bills-endangering-women|archive-date=July 2, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> He has said that he personally believes life begins at [[Fetal viability|viability]] but that "it's not up to people like me to be making these decisions".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Frazin |first1=Rachel |title=2020 Dem Steve Bullock: I think life begins at viability |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/444444-bullock-i-think-life-begins-at-viability |website=[[Great Falls Tribune]] |date=August 3, 2018}}</ref>
 
 ===Campaign finance reform===
 As Attorney General of Montana, Bullock advocated on behalf of the state's century-old ban on corporate money in elections, the Montana Corrupt Practices Act of 1912. After that and similar laws were struck down by the U.S. Supreme Court's ''[[Citizens United]]'' decision in 2010, Bullock countered with a new case, ''American Tradition Partnership, Inc. v. Bullock'' (2012). The Supreme Court disposed of the case in a 5–4 decision,<ref>{{cite web |title=AMERICAN TRADITION PARTNERSHIP, INC. v. BULLOCK |url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/supremecourt/text/11-1179 |website=Legal Information Institute |publisher=Cornell Law School |accessdate=September 4, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180904192224/https://www.law.cornell.edu/supremecourt/text/11-1179 |archive-date=September 4, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref> but Bullock continued to advocate for campaign finance reform throughout his time as governor of Montana.<ref name="Billings Gazette">{{cite web |last1=Johnson |first1=Charles S. |title=Bullock signs Montana campaign finance bill into law |url=https://billingsgazette.com/news/government-and-politics/bullock-signs-montana-campaign-finance-bill-into-law/article_c8a0cc59-a7bf-5381-9136-ae118d9a13ff.html |website=Billings Gazette |accessdate=September 4, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180904191908/https://billingsgazette.com/news/government-and-politics/bullock-signs-montana-campaign-finance-bill-into-law/article_c8a0cc59-a7bf-5381-9136-ae118d9a13ff.html |archive-date=September 4, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Memoli |first1=Mike |title=Montana governor pushes for more transparency on donors |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/card/montana-governor-pushes-more-transparency-donors-n880316 |website=NBC News |accessdate=September 4, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180905052524/https://www.nbcnews.com/card/montana-governor-pushes-more-transparency-donors-n880316 |archive-date=September 5, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref>
 
 In 2015, Bullock steered the DISCLOSE Act, a bipartisan campaign finance reform bill that bolstered disclosure requirements in Montana elections, through a GOP-controlled state legislature.<ref name="Billings Gazette"/><ref>{{Cite AV media |people=Soboroff, Jacob |title=MSNBC's American Swamp: Governor Bullock leading the fight against dark money in politics |medium=Video |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uyL2h8e0CNI |publisher=Steve Bullock <!-- Official YouTube account --> |location= |date=July 29, 2019 |time= }}</ref>
 
 In June 2018, Bullock signed an executive order that required the recipients of major government contracts in Montana to disclose "[[dark money]] spending" in elections, including spending disclosure not explicitly required by federal law.<ref>{{cite web |agency=Associated Press |title=Bullock tells Montana contractors to report 'dark money' |url=https://coloradopolitics.com/out-west-roundup-bullock-tells-montana-contractors-report-dark-money/ |website=CP: Colorado Politics |accessdate=September 4, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180904192022/https://coloradopolitics.com/out-west-roundup-bullock-tells-montana-contractors-report-dark-money/ |archive-date=September 4, 2018 |url-status=live  }}</ref>

 ''[[The Atlantic]]'' called him the "secret diplomatic weapon" deployed against some of the thorniest foreign policy challenges of the US.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kralev|first1=Nicholas|title=The White House's Secret Diplomatic Weapon|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2013/04/the-white-houses-secret-diplomatic-weapon/274655/|accessdate=30 June 2014|work=The Atlantic|date=April 4, 2013}}</ref>
 
 === Carnegie Endowment for International Peace ===
 Burns was appointed the ninth President of the [[Carnegie Endowment for International Peace]] on February 4, 2015, where he leads a global network of 140 scholars across 20 countries and six centers.
 
 Burns was widely assumed to be on the shortlist of the nominees of presidential candidate [[Hillary Clinton]] for Secretary of State,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2016/08/hillary-clinton-john-kerry-secretary-state-226740|title=Would Hillary keep John Kerry on?|first=Michael|last=Crowley|website=POLITICO}}</ref> and is reported by POLITICO to be a possible contender for presidential candidate [[Joe Biden]]'s Secretary of State as well.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Toosi |first1=Nahal |title=The race to be Biden’s secretary of State is already underway |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/10/19/joe-biden-secretary-of-state-430089 |website=POLITICO |accessdate=19 October 2020 |language=en}}</ref>
 
 ===Publications===
 His bestselling memoir, ''[https://carnegieendowment.org/2019/01/25/back-channel-memoir-of-american-diplomacy-and-case-for-its-renewal-pub-78072 The Back Channel: A Memoir of American Diplomacy and the Case for Its Renewal]'', was published by [[Random House]] in 2019. It was published in conjunction with an [https://carnegieendowment.org/publications/interactive/back-channel/ archive] of nearly 100 declassified diplomatic cables. For ''The Back Channel'', Burns received The Douglas Dillon Book Award for Books of Distinction on the Practice of American Diplomacy (2019).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.academyofdiplomacy.org/recipient/william-burns/|title=William Burns|website=The American Academy of Diplomacy}}</ref> 
 
 In 2019, he was made a contributing writer at The Atlantic magazine.
 
 Burns writes regularly on US foreign policy and diplomacy for the ''New York Times'', ''Washington Post'', ''Foreign Affairs'', and other publications.<ref name="auto">{{Cite web|url=https://carnegieendowment.org/experts/1014|title=William J. Burns|website=Carnegie Endowment for International Peace}}</ref>
 
-His Oxford dissertation was published in 1985 as [https://www.amazon.com/Economic-American-Policy-Toward-1955-1981/dp/0873958691 ''Economic Aid and American Policy Toward Egypt, 1955–1981''].
+His Oxford dissertation was published in 1985 as ''Economic Aid and American Policy Toward Egypt, 1955–1981''.
 
 == Awards ==
 Burns is the recipient of three [[President's Award for Distinguished Federal Civilian Service|Presidential Distinguished Service Awards]] and a number of [[Awards of the United States Department of State|Department of State awards]], including three [[Secretary's Distinguished Service Award]]s, the [[Secretary's Career Achievement Award]], the [[Awards of the United States Department of State#Charles E. Cobb Jr. Award for Initiative and Success in Trade Development|Charles E. Cobb, Jr. Ambassadorial Award for Initiative and Success in Trade Development]] (2006), the [[Awards of the United States Department of State#Robert C. Frasure Memorial Award|Robert C. Frasure Memorial Award]] (2005), and the [[Awards of the United States Department of State|James Clement Dunn Award]] (1991). He also received the [[Department of Defense Award for Distinguished Public Service]] (2014), the U.S. Intelligence Community Medallion (2014), and the Central Intelligence Agency's [[Agency Seal Medal]] (2014). 
 
 In 1994, Burns was named to [[TIME Magazine|''TIME'' Magazine]]'s lists of "50 Most Promising American Leaders Under Age 40" and "100 Most Promising Global Leaders Under Age 40".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://time.com/3618532/future-leaders-of-the-1990s/|title=What Happened to the 'Future Leaders' of the 1990s?|website=Time}}</ref>  He was named ''[[Foreign Policy]]''<nowiki/>'s "Diplomat of the Year" in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bill Burns Honored as Diplomat of the Year|url=http://thecable.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2013/06/12/bill_burns_honored_as_diplomat_of_the_year|website=foreignpolicy.com|publisher=Foreign Policy|accessdate=30 June 2014}}</ref>  He is the recipient of [[Anti-Defamation League]]'s Distinguished Statesman Award (2014),<ref>{{cite web|title=Deputy Secretary of State Bill Burns Presented with ADL Award|url=http://www.adl.org/press-center/press-releases/miscellaneous/deputy-secretary-of-state-bill-burns-presented-with-adl-award.html|website=www.adl.org|accessdate=30 June 2014}}</ref> the [[Middle East Institute]]'s Lifetime Achievement Award (2014), and the [[American Academy of Diplomacy]]'s Annenberg Award for Diplomatic Excellence (2015).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.academyofdiplomacy.org/award/annenberg-excellence-in-diplomacy-award/|title=Walter and Leonore Annenberg Excellence in Diplomacy Award|website=The American Academy of Diplomacy}}</ref>
 
 Burns holds four honorary doctoral degrees and is a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.<ref name="auto"/> He is also an honorary Fellow, St. John's College, Oxford (from 2012).<ref>{{cite web|title=RAI in America|url=http://www.rai.ox.ac.uk/about/RAI-in-America|website=www.rai.ox.ac.uk|accessdate=30 June 2014}}</ref>

 {{Elections in North Carolina}}
 An election will be held on November 3, 2020 to elect all 50 members to [[North Carolina]]'s [[North Carolina Senate|Senate]]. The election will coincide with the [[2020 North Carolina elections|elections]] for other offices, including the [[2020 United States presidential election in North Carolina|Presidency]], [[2020 United States Senate election in North Carolina|U.S Senate]], [[2020 North Carolina gubernatorial election|Governor]], [[2020 United States House of Representatives elections in North Carolina|U.S. House of Representatives]], and [[2020 North Carolina House of Representatives election|state house]]. The [[primary election]] was held on March 3, 2020 with a run-off on June 23, 2020.<ref>[https://s3.amazonaws.com/dl.ncsbe.gov/Elections/2020/2020_General_Election_Candidates/20201103_state_and_county_candidate_list_grouped_by_contest_FINAL.pdf]"North Carolina genral election candidates"</ref><ref>[https://er.ncsbe.gov/?election_dt=03/03/2020&county_id=0&office=NCS&contest=0]"North Carolina State Board of elections"</ref>

 The '''2020 United States Senate election in Massachusetts''' was held on November 3, 2020, to elect a member of the [[United States Senate]] to represent the [[Commonwealth of Massachusetts]], concurrently with the [[2020 U.S. presidential election]], as well as [[2020 United States Senate elections|elections]] to the United States Senate in other states, [[2020 United States House of Representatives elections|elections]] to the [[United States House of Representatives]] and various [[2020 United States elections|state and local elections]]. On September 1, incumbent Senator [[Ed Markey]] defeated U.S. Representative [[Joe Kennedy III]] in a competitive primary for the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] nomination and Kevin O'Connor defeated [[Shiva Ayyadurai]] for the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] nomination.
 
 ==Democratic primary==
 The state primary election took place on September 1, 2020.<ref name=":0">{{cite web |url=https://www.sec.state.ma.us/CalendarWeb/Pages/MonthWeekCalendar.aspx |title= Election calendar|website= www.sec.state.ma.us|format=PDF|access-date=2020-08-03}}</ref> Incumbent Senator [[Ed Markey]] was challenged by U.S. Representative [[Joe Kennedy III]]. Kennedy and Markey have similar political positions, though Markey is considered more liberal on the [[NOMINATE (scaling method)|DW-Nominate]] scale.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Rakich|first=Nathaniel|date=2019-09-24|title=Joe Kennedy Isn't Your Usual Upstart Primary Challenger|url=https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/joe-kennedy-wants-to-unseat-a-senator-hes-not-your-usual-primary-challenger/|access-date=2020-09-02|website=FiveThirtyEight|language=en-US}}</ref> An elected senator has not been defeated in a primary since [[Richard Lugar]] in [[2012 United States Senate election in Indiana|2012]], and an elected Democrat has not been defeated since [[Joe Lieberman]] in [[2006 United States Senate election in Connecticut|2006]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Jacobson|first=Louis|title=Markey vs. Kennedy: Welcome to the most unusual Senate primary in decades – Sabato's Crystal Ball|url=https://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/markey-vs-kennedy-welcome-to-the-most-unusual-senate-primary-in-decades/|access-date=2020-08-30|language=en-US}}. [[Arlen Specter]], who was elected as a Republican but switched parties to Democratic, was defeated in [[2010 United States Senate election in Pennsylvania|2010]] during his first Democratic primary.</ref>

 The '''2020 North Carolina lieutenant gubernatorial election''' took place on November 3, 2020, to elect the [[Lieutenant Governor of North Carolina]], concurrently with the [[2020 United States presidential election|2020 U.S. presidential election]], as well as [[United States Senate elections, 2020|elections]] to the [[United States Senate]] and [[United States House of Representatives elections, 2020|elections]] to the [[United States House of Representatives]] and various [[United States elections, 2020#State elections|state]] and [[United States elections, 2020#Local elections|local elections]]. Primary elections were held on March 3, 2020.
 
 In North Carolina, the [[North Carolina Governor|Governor]] and Lieutenant Governor are elected separately.
 
 Incumbent [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Lieutenant Governor [[Dan Forest]] was re-elected to a second term in 2016, despite Republican Governor [[Pat McCrory]] losing reelection by a narrow margin.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Leslie |first1=Laura |title=Split-ticket voting leads to mix of Democratic, Republican wins in NC |url=https://www.wral.com/split-ticket-voting-leads-to-mix-of-democratic-republican-wins-in-nc/16219118/ |website=WRAL |date=November 9, 2016}}</ref> Forest was ineligible to run for a third term due to [[term limits]] established by the [[Constitution of North Carolina]]. He instead unsuccessfully [[2020 North Carolina gubernatorial election|ran for Governor]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Dan Forest will hold campaign kick off rally in August|url=https://nsjonline.com/article/2019/07/dan-forest-will-hold-campaign-kick-off-rally-in-august/|newspaper=North State Journal|date=July 10, 2019|accessdate=July 10, 2019}}</ref>
 
 The Republican Party nominated businessman [[Mark Robinson (American politician)|Mark Robinson]] (who was running for public office for the first time), and the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] nominated state representative [[Yvonne Lewis Holley]]. No matter who won, North Carolina would elect its first African-American lieutenant governor. Robinson won the general election, even while Democratic incumbent Gov. Roy Cooper won reelection.
 
 ==Republican primary==
 ===Candidates===
 ====Nominee====
 *[[Mark Robinson (American politician)|Mark Robinson]], businessman<ref>{{cite web |title=The NCGOP’s Lt. Gov. Candidate Apparently Thinks the Coronavirus Is a “Globalist” Conspiracy to Destroy Donald Trump |url=https://indyweek.com/news/northcarolina/ncgop-lieutenant-governor-mark-robinson-coronavirus-globalist/?fbclid=IwAR3jMwEKFSuGyeonY1N47_knXbgLIcQt5T4HpfxS3ENIiOqVI91wlpmumy8 |website=Indy Week |accessdate=March 30, 2020 |date=March 27, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Man whose pro-gun speech went viral announces candidacy for lieutenant governor |url=https://www.richmondobserver.com/national-news/item/5229-man-whose-pro-gun-speech-went-viral-announces-candidacy-for-lieutenant-governor.html |website=The Richmond Observer |accessdate=September 15, 2019 |date=July 3, 2019}}</ref>
